text: Hello folks. I have a question reg. measuring the RoI of content ( in b2b context). I see lot of articles and lot of experts talk about things like how many leads were generated or how many conversions happened through the content, but as we probably realize, these metrics are for b2c. Recently, a client approached me to write a bunch of pillar blog posts covering the subject matter behind their product. The discussion went into a spiraling argument where he was asking me to justify the cost X of one content piece to derive a value Y for his company. This got me thinking because I do not have a tangible value proposition for him that can be calculated like the metrics of b2c context. Any help, suggestions or insights would be a great.

elements.text: Hello folks. I have a question reg. measuring the RoI of content ( in b2b context). I see lot of articles and lot of experts talk about things like how many leads were generated or how many conversions happened through the content, but as we probably realize, these metrics are for b2c. Recently, a client approached me to write a bunch of pillar blog posts covering the subject matter behind their product. The discussion went into a spiraling argument where he was asking me to justify the cost X of one content piece to derive a value Y for his company. This got me thinking because I do not have a tangible value proposition for him that can be calculated like the metrics of b2c context. Any help, suggestions or insights would be a great.

text: How expensive is his product?

elements.text: How expensive is his product?

text: Its is mid-tier SaaS product. So not very expensive, at the same time not a commodity product either.

elements.text: Its is mid-tier SaaS product. So not very expensive, at the same time not a commodity product either.

text: You can measure immediate ROI by tracking conversions in Google Analytics, but honestly this is a tricky question. If the content isn't getting good distribution, then the ROI is probably lower. Distribution can be SEO, social, paid social, email, or other means, but if you don't have a way to get eyeballs on the newly created content, you're going to get poor ROI.

elements.text: You can measure immediate ROI by tracking conversions in Google Analytics, but honestly this is a tricky question. If the content isn't getting good distribution, then the ROI is probably lower. Distribution can be SEO, social, paid social, email, or other means, but if you don't have a way to get eyeballs on the newly created content, you're going to get poor ROI.

text:
>  leads were generated or how many conversions happened through the content, but as we probably realize, these metrics are for b2c
Hrm, I think those metrics are more b2b than b2c.

B2c doesn't usually work on leads... and conversions can apply to both.

For b2b the formula isn't too crazy IMO:

*Start with:* Avg value of closed deal, use LTV if you can. Say it's $10,000.

*Then:* avg number of leads needed to close a deal. Get granular if you have the data. Say it's 15 leads or a close ratio of 6.67%

Therefore value of a lead = $667 to breakeven

Cost per lead needs to be pegged to this number. Startup looking for traction? Your cost per lead (or cost per acquisition in this case) could be at a 1:1 ratio (i.e. $667), or even underwater if taking losses is fine at this point.

For an established company, you may be looking to aim for 3x, so spend no more than $222 getting a lead.

Now you come to content conversion funnels. If you spend $222 to get 5000 eyeballs, the end result needs to be at least one lead. Math out all the conversion checkpoints along the way

seconding grow & convert, we use a similar model at AM. you can definitely track conversions for b2b.

i'd avoid working with a freelance client who's already arguing about the value of the work

text: Thanks <@ULKUFTFPW>. The deeper issue here is (this is what I understand) about convincing clients of tangible value adds. We can mention the distribution channels but this client ( and many others) wants to see some tangible numbers in terms of revenue generated / time saved etc...  Surely the numbers will multiple with better outreach and amplification.

text: Hi all -- does anyone have recommendations for a graphic designer who can help design an ebook? The book will be published by a B2B SaaS company, and targeted towards execs. It will involve laying out text and graphic elements, as well as designing a few text-based infographics. Thanks!

text: I've found that unless you control or get to work with the team(s) controlling content strategy, content development, content distribution and advertising, AND marketing automation - and get data from all those points - you can't accurately speak to the specific dollar sign value of any piece of content.

text: If you want to illustrate the problem with this line of thinking/inquiry, ask the client what a casino's ROI is on a hand of blackjack.

elements.text: If you want to illustrate the problem with this line of thinking/inquiry, ask the client what a casino's ROI is on a hand of blackjack.

text: It's a nonsensical question (like the one you're being asked) since the casino is playin a probability game and its business model isn't winning _a hand_, but rather playing enough hands that it always wins.  Any game with variable outcomes (e.g. casino games, content creation, to name two) is about stacking the odds in your favor and then playing the odds as a long game.

elements.text: It's a nonsensical question (like the one you're being asked) since the casino is playin a probability game and its business model isn't winning
a hand

, but rather playing enough hands that it always wins.  Any game with variable outcomes (e.g. casino games, content creation, to name two) is about stacking the odds in your favor and then playing the odds as a long game.

text: We do a lot of ROI modeling for clients and the thing I tell them is that content, done right, is like gambling, but where you're the house/casino

elements.text: We do a lot of ROI modeling for clients and the thing I tell them is that content, done right, is like gambling, but where you're the house/casino

text: (As a practical aside, a really easy way to demonstrate ROI that doesn't involve climbing into every conversion point in the funnel is to compare the content cost to PPC spend.)

elements.text: (As a practical aside, a really easy way to demonstrate ROI that doesn't involve climbing into every conversion point in the funnel is to compare the content cost to PPC spend.)

text:
Hey B2B content folks!
I'm in the final phases of creating my Product-led content marketing report. It's based on public traffic, content, and SEO data of <https://openviewpartners.com/blog/the-product-led-growth-market-map#.YSW3wY4zZPY|50 PLG companies>.

I'm looking for insights/quotes to include alongside the data-points. Since I've gotten so much from the SuperPath community, I thought, I'd reach out and check if anyone of you is interested.

I will be considering quotes to include based on a first come first serve basis (and their value of course). But, I'll also include the rest of the quotes in a blog post that accompanies the report.

If you're, here's the report: <https://bit.ly/3iYLs3k>
And, here's the quote submission form: <https://bit.ly/3gjXRgx>

Thanks!
